bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, April 8, 1953

div1.p: Hench informs Blossom Reed that he will be happy to help her with the sale of her father's books. He discusses what makes books and autographs valuable.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, April 8, 1953
div1.opener:
April 8, 1953
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I shall be glad to help you with the sale of the seven books of your father's.
The difficulty however is that second-hand medical book stores do not specialize
particularly in autographed books; whereas autograph stores concern themselves
almost entirely with letters and manuscripts and do not bother with books.
Therefore an autographed book unfortunately rather falls between two commercial
groups and I have seen many a catalog listing a book autographed by a famous
man in which the price was based exclusively or almost so on the value of the
book, perhaps with a dollar added for the signature.

Another thing about old medical books is that their value is not derived from
their date particularly but from a combination of two things: (1) their lasting
value; that is, if they were a classic and (2) their rarity. Many a book that
is quite rare, but of which the contents are rather worthless or entirely out
of date, one can buy for two or three dollars.

I should think that the sale of your father's seven books would be more profitable
to you if they were put in the hands of someone interested in them simply and
solely because they were your father's books and not because they are inherently
worth this or that. I do not, off-hand, know the merit of the seven books you
mention but having been a book-buyer and book-lover for years, I must in all
honesty tell you that the dates of these books fall “in between.” By that I
mean valuable books between 1600 and 1830 or 40, command a fair price but even
so they have to fulfill the criteria mentioned above. Or a valuable book that
is just out of print, maybe ten years old, but is still pertinent, may command a
price. Those not between these dates have extremely variable values, depending
entirely upon the book itself and not on the age.

Now I do want to help you and it would certainly be easy for me to write to
three or four institutions or places that might want these books for the reason
mentioned. Do you have any idea what you would want for the seven books. I
can ask our librarian to give me a little idea as to their intrinsic merit as
books of a certain date. That would be the basis with the extra cose because of
their very real sentimental value. If you do set a price, I will keep it con-
fidential and will not of course pass it on to anyone without your permission
but it will give me some idea as to who one should tackle - whether some individual
of modest means interested in your father (and I know many) or some library or
military institution. When I hear from you also I can either send you the names
of three or four second-hand medical book stores in New York; also the names of
the three or four best autograph stores.-

Of course (and please do not misunderstand me) I should like to have the first
chance at buying the books myself but I fear that this would embarrass you as
you do want the best price you can get for them and until we explore the matter
I haven't any idea what that might be or whether I could meet it; however that
is not important. The only important thing is that these books which you have
cherished for these many years shall be put in the hands of others who will
cherish them almost as well and in the process you will get a fair price. That
I will certainly be glad to help you do.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
